Critical thinking

a. ‘All children have the right to quality education. How can we ensure this right to every child? Discuss the role of the government and the parents to make sure that every child can attend school.’


Ans: To ensure every child's right to quality education:

Governments must make primary and secondary education free and compulsory by law for all children. They need to adequately fund schools and vocational training institutions.

Governments and schools must work to minimize costs like textbooks, uniforms etc to improve accessibility for poor families.

Parents need to realize the importance of education. They must enroll their children in school and support their education by providing necessities and a conducive home environment for learning.


b.’Do you think that there is still discrimination between sons and daughters in terms of providing education in our country? What strategies do you suggest to overcome such discrimination against girls?’


Ans: In many parts of our country, daughters still do not receive equal opportunities in education as sons due to social and economic barriers. Some strategies to overcome this discrimination are:

  • Scholarships/incentives for girls' enrollment and retention in schools to reduce financial burden on parents.
  • Setting up more girls' schools and improving safety/sanitation facilities to encourage attendance.
  • Stricter implementation of laws punishing denial of girls' education.


c. ‘A Chinese philosopher Confucius said, “If your plan is for one year, plant rice; if your plan is for ten years, plant trees; if your plan is for one hundred years, educate children.” What is the meaning of this saying? Elaborate this with examples.’


Ans: Confucius' saying emphasizes the long-term impact of education. It means that by investing in the education of children, we are planting the seeds for a better future.


Planting Rice (1 year) refers to immediate needs. If you focus on short-term goals, like planting rice, you'll have food for the present but not much for the future. Planting Trees (10 years) means that trees take longer to grow but provide fruits, wood, and shade. Educating Children has a profound and lasting impact on society. By educating children, we empower future generations to lead, innovate, and contribute positively to society for centuries.

b. What is cyber bullying? What are its effects? How can it be stopped? 

Cyberbullying is when someone uses the internet, social media, or other digital platforms to hurt, intimidate, or harm others. It can involve things like sending mean messages, spreading rumors, or posting embarrassing photos or videos.


The effects of cyberbullying can be very negative:

Emotional Impact: It can make victims feel sad, scared, or anxious. They may lose confidence, have low self-esteem, and feel isolated or lonely.

Academic Problems: Cyberbullying can interfere with a victim's ability to focus on schoolwork, leading to difficulties in studying, lower grades, and a negative impact on their education.

Social Isolation: Victims may avoid social situations, both online and offline, due to fear or embarrassment. This can result in feeling alone and having trouble making or maintaining friendships.

Physical Symptoms: Cyberbullying can cause physical health issues like headaches, stomachaches, or trouble sleeping due to stress and anxiety.


To stop cyberbullying, we can take these steps:

Raise Awareness: Talk about cyberbullying at school and home. Teach others about its harmful effects and encourage empathy, kindness, and respect online.

Report and Seek Help: If you or someone you know is a victim of cyberbullying, tell a trusted adult, such as a parent, teacher, or school counselor. They can provide support and guidance.

Save Evidence: Keep a record of any cyberbullying incidents, such as screenshots or messages. This evidence can be used to report the bullying to the appropriate authorities.

Block and Ignore: Block or unfriend the cyberbully to stop their messages or posts from reaching you. Ignore their hurtful comments and refuse to engage with them.

Privacy Settings: Adjust your privacy settings on social media platforms to control who can see your posts and personal information. Limiting access can help prevent cyberbullying.

Be a Good Digital Citizen: Treat others online with kindness and respect. Think before sharing or commenting, and avoid participating in or spreading cyberbullying.

"The Oval Portrait" is a short horror story about a portrait in an abandoned mansion. It is written in a nested story format, also called story within story format. It has two, ie. outer and inner narrative.

The inner story focuses on the artist and his wife. It follows their lives and the sad events leading up to the portrait's completion.


By using this frame narrative, the story has more layers. We see the events from the outside perspective of the narrator finding the book. And from the inside view of what actually happened to the artist and wife.

The book within the story, serving as a narrative device and a symbol of hidden knowledge.

The woman's beauty and her portrayal in the portrait, symbolizing the artist's obsession and the cost of artistic perfection.

William Shakespeare's poem "All the world's a stage" is from his play "As You Like It." It presents a metaphorical perspective on the stages of human life and the roles people play. Let's break down the poem's meaning and hidden messages:

"His acts being seven ages.": Shakespeare divides a person's life into seven stages, each with its characteristics and challenges. These stages represent the journey from infancy to old age.


"At first, the infant, Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms.": The first stage is infancy, where a baby is helpless and dependent, represented by the image of crying and vomiting in the nurse's arms.

title: 5. The Gift in Wartime
story:
The Gift in Wartime


Written by The SR Zone | Shriram Lamichhane


Exercise

Understanding the text

Answer the following questions.


a. Who is the speaker addressing and why can that person not hear or understand what she is saying?

→ The speaker is actually addressing her husband who died on a war. He cannot hear or understand what she is saying because he is dead.


b. What can you infer about the speaker’s feelings for the person addressed as “you”?

→ The speaker's feelings for the person addressed as "you" are characterized by deep love and grief. The poem suggests that they were once in love, and the speaker's mourning and longing for the lost loved one are evident throughout the poem.


c. What is the speaker’s attitude toward war?

→ The speaker has a negative outlook on war. During the Vietnam War, she lost her husband, whom she loved more than anything in the world. He hasn't been there for her, and it's made her miserable.


d. In what ways do you think this person’s fate has affected the speaker?

→ The person's fate has affected the speaker profoundly, causing her to experience the loss of love, youth, and happiness. The Speaker has lost her husband in war whom she loves the most. While serving in the American-Vietnamese battle, he was killed by a bomb. Widowhood has left the speaker feeling isolated all alone in the world. She is not able to recover the pain of losing her most loved person. 


e. What does the speaker promise at the end of the poem? Why do you think the speaker does this?

→ The speaker promises to meet her husband in another life. She wants to keep the shrapnel (metal pieces) as a way to identify each other. This shows how much she deeply cares for the person she calls "you". It means her love and missing them will continue forever. This gives hope that their connection will go on beyond this physical world.


Reference to the text


a. What is the theme of the poem?

The theme of the poem revolves around love, loss, and the devastating impact of war on personal lives.


b. What imagery from the poem made the greatest impression on you? Why?

The poem uses strong imageries to show the difference between what the speaker gives her love compared to what she gets back. She offers romantic things like roses, her wedding dress, and her youthfulness. But in return, she gets military items like his husband's honors, the smell of blood and his dead body. This big difference effectively shows how war has changed her emotionally and physically. The poem uses this contrast to deeply express how war can harm relationships and in personal level of people. It powerfully comments on war's tragic impacts.


c. Which figurative language is used in the poem? Explain with examples.

The poem uses many non-literal meanings which is also called figurative language. This poem uses irony, apostrophe, anaphora and metaphor to express deeper meanings beyond the literal words. Figurative language makes the message more powerful.


Irony is when words mean the opposite of what they say. The speaker talks of "gifts" from war but really means the sadness it caused. Apostrophe addresses someone not there, like speaking to her dead husband. Anaphora repeats the same words, like "I offer you" at the start of lines. Similarly, metaphor compares two unlike things that share something, likening her sorrow to summer clouds.


d. What does the speaker “offer” in this poem? What does the person addressed as “you” give in return?

The speaker offers her feelings, love, youth, memories and things that remind her of their love to the person she calls "you". But all she get back are military medals, stars and the smell of blood from the war.


e. An apostrophe is a literary device in which a writer or speaker addresses an absent person or an abstract idea in such a way as if it were present and can be understood. Discuss the poem in relation to the apostrophe.

The speaker uses an apostrophe to mention her late husband. By doing so, she has been able to communicate her emotions and her sorrow to him in a straightforward manner. This helps her in lowering her pain and sorrow. She was also able to deliver the message and make the commitment to meet again in the future by addressing the missing "you."


Reference beyond the text

a. One way to get relief from grief is to write or talk about it. In your opinion, how might the speaker in this poem have benefitted from saying what she did? Explain.


When we share our sorrow, our pain reduces a bit because we can get sympathy by sharing our pain. The speaker was able to lessen the pain of her wartime experience for her listeners and viewers by emphasizing the actions and efforts she made in her solitary life. When a person gets wounded in war, it affects everyone around them, not just the one who is injured. One of the most helpful things the speaker did was write a poem in memory of her late husband. She is more at ease now that she thinks she has talked with him face to face. Assurance that they will reunite in the hereafter warms her heart. The speaker has used a wide range of literary strategies to make her feelings of grief, sadness, and love for the deceased, as well as her anger and horror at war, clear to the audience.


b. Write an essay on the effects of war.

War is a really bad thing that hurts a lot of people and places. War affects individuals, communities, and whole countries. The bad effects of war last a long time.


First, war causes physical harm. It hurts and kills many soldiers and civilians. It destroys homes, neighborhoods, and cities. Families break apart and people are left with scars and disabilities. The damage to things like hospitals, schools, and services makes the suffering worse.


Second, the psychological impact of war can't be understated. Soldiers experience trauma which can lead to things like PTSD. Civilians who are caught in the middle feel immense stress and fear for their lives. The mental scars of war can stick around even after the fighting is over, affecting people's mental health and well-being.


Also, war disrupts societies and tears communities apart. Forced moves, refugee crises, and breakdowns in social structure leave deep wounds. Families are separated, and the bonds that hold groups of people together are strained. The loss of trust and problems with social cohesion can slow recovery for a long time after peace.


Economically, war takes resources away from important sectors like education, healthcare, and infrastructure. The cost of conflict uses funds that could otherwise help human development. Economies after war often struggle to get better, making life harder for countries and increasing poverty.


In conclusion, war has deep and terrible effects. It causes injuries, trauma, turmoil in societies, and financial difficulties. The scars of war stick around even after the fighting stops, reminding us of humanity's ability to both destroy and rebuild. Efforts to prevent and lessen the impacts of war remain crucial for a more peaceful and caring world.

title: 1. Sharing Tradition

Understanding the texts

Answer the following questions.

a. According to LaPena, what is the importance of the oral tradition? To what extent do you agree with his opinions and why?

He says that it's important for each person to pass on what they have learned in life so the next generation becomes more practical and aware. I agree with him because oral tradition is key in preserving our cultural heritage and sharing knowledge from one generation to the next. Oral tradition uses speaking to share stories, histories, and knowledge from parents to children and between generations. Literary tradition uses writing instead. The Difficulty of Passing Knowledge: This problem highlights the challenge of transmitting cultural knowledge from elders to younger generations effectively.

Issues with Modern Education: He addresses how modern education systems does not prioritize oral traditions and may lead to a disconnect from cultural values.

Lastly, celebrating cultural events brings our community together and shows the beauty of our traditions. Participating in these keeps our culture vibrant.

It makes their characters more interesting because we understand their connection now. It adds feelings to the scene when they see each other again after a long time. We can feel sad and happy for them at the same time.


h. Discuss how the play is built around humour and irony.

The play is funny in how the characters Dona Laura and Don Gonzalo pretend to be different people. This causes silly mistakes and confused moments. They used to love each other very much, but now they don't even know who the other person is because of their disguises. We the audience know the truth about them, which makes the situations they get into even funnier. The mistakes and confusing identities provide humor. And the irony of their past relationship compared to now adds to the comedy. This helps make the overall play lighthearted and entertaining to read instead of heavy or serious.


i. How is the title ‘A Sunny Morning’ justifiable? Discuss.

The title "A Sunny Morning" is justifiable because it sets the tone for the play and reflects its overall mood. The story takes place on a beautiful, sunny morning, which symbolizes a fresh start and a sense of optimism. The sunny weather creates a cheerful atmosphere that complements the humorous and romantic elements of the play. Additionally, the title serves as a metaphor for the character's desire to escape their past troubles and enjoy a bright and hopeful future. Overall, the title captures the essence of the play, emphasizing the positive and uplifting aspects of the story.


Reference beyond the text

a. What do you predict will happen in the next meeting between Dona Laura and Don Gonzalo? Discuss.

In the next meeting between Dona Laura and Don Gonzalo, it's likely that the full truth about their past relationship and identities will be revealed. Now that their true identities will be out in the open, they may talk about their past relationship and how they used to be in love. They will likely feel nostalgic and happy, but also maybe sad about the time they spent apart. This reunion could bring them emotionally closer as they discuss their feelings. It may resolve all the confusion that has happened so far from pretending to be different people. Learning the whole story about each other could lead them to reconnect in a deep way. The play has been hinting at this reveal, so their meeting will likely be an important moment where everything comes to light between them.


b. Was it wise for Dona Laura and Don Gonzalo to keep their identities secret? How might their secrets affect future meetings?

Keeping their identities secret initially allowed Dona Laura and Don Gonzalo to enjoy a fresh start and escape from their troubled pasts. However, their secrets have also led to misunderstandings and missed opportunities for reconnection. In future meetings, now that they have recognized each other, their secrets may no longer be necessary. Instead, they can openly discuss their shared history and their feelings. While their secrets initially added humor and irony to the play, their revelation may lead to a more genuine and heartfelt relationship.


C. Write a play summary.

"A Sunny Morning" is a one-act comedy play by Serafin and Joaquin Alvarez Quintero. It revolves around the chance encounter of two strangers, Dona Laura and Don Gonzalo, on a sunny morning. Both are escaping their pasts and have adopted false identities to enjoy anonymity. As they share their life stories, they gradually realize that they were once deeply in love but separated due to misunderstandings and societal pressures. The play explores themes of mistaken identity, humor, and the power of love. In the end, they recognize each other, and their true identities are revealed, setting the stage for a potentially heartfelt reunion.

Understanding the text

Answer the following Questions

a. Why does Wasserkopf demand a refund of his tuition fees from the school?

Wasserkopf demands a tuition refund from the school because he believes the money he spent on education wasn’t worth it as it left him unprepared for life. He feels that he has learned nothing and has no useful knowledge to show for the money he paid in tuition.


b. Why does Wasserkopf consider himself good for nothing?

Wasserkopf considers himself good at nothing because he was always rejected on job applications and unable to do nothing great.


c. What did the teachers decide to do when Wasserkopf asked for a refund?

The professors decided to take a re-examination of him and pass him in all subjects even if he gives wrong answers. They came to the conclusion that they should collaboratively work with each other in defending the refund demand of Wasserkopf.


d. Why did Wasserkopf give ridiculous answers? Why did the teachers accept these answers?

He gave ridiculous answers in order to fail and be eligible for refund. His answers were accepted by the professors they wanted to prove him wrong and demonstrate that he had indeed learned something during his time at the school to avoid the refund that he was asking for.


e. How does the Mathematics Master describe Wasserkopf’s character?

The Mathematical Master sees Wasserkopf as someone who is clever at manipulating situations to his advantage. The Master believes Wasserkopf will use any strategy to get back the money he paid for his education. He thinks Wasserkopf is tricky and will do a lot to regain his refund.


f. How did the teachers outwit Wasserkopf?

The professors tricked Wasserkopf using reverse psychology. They asked him very easy questions to make him think he passed the test. But Wasserkopf defended that with his wrong answers with silly justifications. Finally, math teacher admitted Wasserkopf failed. He asked Wasserkopf to calculate how much the school owed him in refund. Wasserkopf correctly gave the exact refund amount. The math professors said Wasserkopf must be a math genius to solve such a hard refund problem. They announced he passed the test. In the end, the teachers were cleverer than Wasserkopf by using his own tricks against him through their psychological tactics and difficult math question.


g. What is the final judgment on Waserkopf’s demand for refund?

The final judgment on Wasserkopf's demand for a refund is that he is deserving for the certificate that he was awarded during graduation. The teachers successfully demonstrate to him that he has indeed learned valuable knowledge during his time at the school, and he leaves with a newfound appreciation for his education.


Reference to the text

a. Read the extract from the play given below and answer the questions that follow: “It’s possible I’ve changed. What the hell…! Your class records will show I’ve got a right to come here.”


i. Who is the speaker? Who is he speaking to?

Wasserkopf is the speaker. He's speaking to the principal of his former school.


ii. Why does the speaker say these words?

The speaker expresses his dissatisfaction with his former school's academic results, which he earned eighteen years ago, by saying these words.


iii. Where is the speaker at this moment?

The speaker is in the Principal's office at this moment.


b. Read the extract dialogue given below and Ans the questions that follow:


i. What is the answer to ‘How do you do?’

'I am fine' is the answer to 'How do you do'.


ii. Is Wasserkopf’s answer polite enough to the staff?

Wasserkopf's response is not polite. He responds with rudeness, telling the staff to sit down and calling them "loafers."


iii. How does Wasserkopf rebuke the staff?

Wasserkopf rebukes the staff by using disrespectful language and addressing them with contempt.


iv. What does the principal mean by ‘How dare you -’?

The principal's statement, "How dare you -," indicates his shock and displeasure at Wasserkopf's disrespectful behavior. It suggests that Wasserkopf's response was completely inappropriate and disrespectful towards the staff.


c. Explain the following line of the play: “Because I didn’t get my money’s worth, that’s why!”

The line "Because I didn't get my money's worth, that's why!" reflects Wasserkopf's primary motivation for demanding a refund of his tuition fees. He believes that he did not receive the education and knowledge he expected for the money he paid. Wasserkopf is dissatisfied with the quality of education provided by the school, and he feels cheated, which is why he insists on a refund.


d. What is the theme of the play?

The play "Refund" is full of comedy and satire which covers the theme of  value of theoretical knowledge and raises questions about the practical applicability of education. The writer criticises the present educational system, which does not prepare students for a career. It also shows teacher's ability to manage the problem without compromising their school's image. 


E. Sketch the character of Wasserkopf.

Wasserkopf is a smart and tricky person who uses silly and clever tricks to try and get his money back for his school fees. He's not happy with the education he got and thinks it wasn't worth the money he paid. He is really quick-thinking and creative. During exams, he gives silly answers to confuse the teachers. He believes he deserves refund and is really determined to prove his point. But he can also be really arrogant and doesn't show respect to people in authority. In general, Wasserkopf is a complicated character who surprises both the teachers and the audience with his actions.


Reference beyond the text

a. The play is a satire on the present day education system. Do you think that our education system does not prepare students for life? Discuss.


The current education system does not properly prepare students for real life challenges. Many people today are well educated but lack practical skills. Schools focus more on theoretical learning than teaching creativity and problem-solving needed in real jobs. There is a disconnect between what is taught and the demands of the real world. This results in graduates who are not very productive in workplaces. They also lack leadership abilities since education did not give real world experience. Students are not adequately equipped for adulthood because school does not mirror reality.


In short, the education system over-emphasizes academics over life skills training. This leaves graduates unprepared for challenges of the real world. Better alignment is needed between education and practical career demands.


b. Our education system focuses on memorisation rather than creative thinking. Do you think the knowledge imparted by education may not have practical relevance in one’s day-to-day life? Who do you blame for this?

I feel our educational system is accountable for the knowledge obtained in school which cannot be utilised in real life. Education and associated information are distant from creative thinking in today's educational system. The courses are constructed in such a way that they have no practical use in everyday life. 


Students are searching for an easier method of remembering than using their creative thinking. This is the consequence of the present educational system, which has resulted in the passivation of thousands of people's brains. Students seem to be working hard to improve their grades in a number of different ways. They concentrate only on getting good grades and obtaining certificates without using their own creativity.


c. Most of the students want to learn just for examination rather than knowledge. Do you think that certificate will help them in their future career?

Today, the majority of students graduate via shady methods. They're more likely to be seen working hard to memorize the sentences and formulae when it comes to the last two or three months of the test. They spend most of their time preparing for tests, not gaining meaningful knowledge. In the future, there will be a lack of real skills and talents as certificates don't guarantee abilities. If students only prepare for exams and don't properly learn, they won't be qualified for jobs. Relying on tricks to pass tests produces graduates without real-world applicable skills. This quick fix approach results in unproductive members of society long-term. Proper learning is important, not just getting good grades through memorization.
